target.name: KRAS
target.full_name: Kirsten rat sarcoma viral oncogene homolog

investment_thesis.headline: KRAS went from 'undruggable' to approved with sotorasib/adagrasib, now G12D race heats up
key_points: G12C approved: Sotorasib (Amgen) and adagrasib (Mirati) validated drugging KRAS
G12D frontier: Revolution Medicines (RMC-6236) leading with Pan-RAS approach
Degraders emerging: Multiple PROTAC programs targeting KRAS for deeper responses
Combination potential: KRAS inhibitors + SHP2, MEK, EGFR for durability
Resistance challenge: Acquired mutations limit monotherapy durability
investment_thesis.full_text:
KRAS was considered 'undruggable' for 40 years until the breakthrough discovery of covalent G12C inhibitors. Amgen's sotorasib (Lumakras, 2021) and Mirati's adagrasib (Krazati, 2022) validated the target, though clinical responses remain modest (~35% ORR) with limited durability due to resistance.

The next wave focuses on: (1) G12D inhibitors for pancreatic cancer, (2) Pan-RAS(ON) inhibitors blocking multiple mutants, (3) Degraders for potentially deeper knockdown, and (4) Combinations to address resistance. Revolution Medicines leads with RMC-6236, showing promising data across G12 mutations.

The commercial opportunity remains significant given KRAS is mutated in ~25% of all cancers, with G12D (pancreatic) being the largest unaddressed segment.

mechanism.biology: KRAS is a GTPase that cycles between active (GTP-bound) and inactive (GDP-bound) states, driving cell proliferation through RAF-MEK-ERK signaling. Oncogenic mutations lock KRAS in the active state.
mechanism.rationale: Covalent inhibitors (G12C) trap mutant KRAS in inactive state. Newer approaches target the active (ON) state or use degraders to eliminate the protein entirely.
mechanism.unique_value: KRAS mutations are among the most common oncogenic drivers, representing a massive unmet need particularly in pancreatic and colorectal cancer.

market_opportunity.patient_population: ~25% of all cancers have KRAS mutations; G12C (13% NSCLC), G12D (90% pancreatic)
market_opportunity.unmet_need: No approved therapies for G12D; limited durability of G12C monotherapy; need for combinations

key_risks.mitigation: Combinations with SHP2, MEK, or vertical pathway inhibitors

key_risks.risk: G12D proving more challenging than G12C
key_risks.mitigation: Pan-RAS approaches may address multiple mutations
Differentiation through mutation coverage, tissue distribution, combinations

assets.name: Daraxonrasib (RMC-6236)
assets.key_data: 36% ORR in PDAC; 50%+ ORR in NSCLC
assets.differentiator: Pan-RAS(ON) inhibitor; covers multiple G12 mutations

assets.name: RMC-6291
assets.differentiator: Active state inhibitor; different mechanism than sotorasib/adagrasib

assets.name: Opnurasib
assets.differentiator: Novartis development; combo potential with TNO155 (SHP2)
